sub_topic: Calculation of latent heat of fusion of a substance
message_1: What is the latent heat of fusion of a sample of ice if it requires 6000 J of energy to melt 1 kg of ice at 0°C?
message_2:
The latent heat of fusion (L_f) is the amount of energy required to change 1 kg of a substance from the solid phase to the liquid phase at its melting point, without changing its temperature. In this case, we are given the energy required (6000 J) to melt 1 kg of ice at 0°C.

To find the latent heat of fusion, we can use the formula:

L_f = Q / m

where L_f is the latent heat of fusion, Q is the energy required to melt the ice (6000 J), and m is the mass of the ice (1 kg).

L_f = 6000 J / 1 kg

L_f = 6000 J/kg

So, the latent heat of fusion of the sample of ice is 6000 J/kg.
